Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2012 03:24PM - edited Apr 20, 2012 03:27PM by steelersluver My breast surgeon is Dr. McGuire from the same office at Magee as Dr. Johnson.  She referred me to Dr. DeLaCruz for my reconstruction.  My surgery is not until May 11, so I can't comment too thoroughly, but I've been happy with Dr. McGuire. I was not a candidate for DEIP, but they do it in that office.  You can find their info on the Magee page under the Breast Cancer Program (left side of page under Specialty Services), then Plastic and Reconstructive Surgeons toward the bottom of the page in the "Our Experts" link (I can't get a link to post).  Dr. Gimble is in the same office as Dr. DeLaCruz.
Posts.Title: Good reconstruction surgeons in Pittsburgh, PA? kathleen1966 mariwyl

Posts.Content: Jun 8, 2012 01:24PM steelersluver wrote: I had a pocket of swelling on the side (almost right in the armpit but a little more toward the side/chest) the nodes were removed that started right after the first two drains were removed.  I'm not sure if the timing is a coincidence or not, but it was to the point it pulled the incision apart a little.  I didn't get the last 2 drains out for 3 weeks, and it took another week after that for the swelling to go down.  It seemed like it was a combination of swelling and fluid to me, but the surgeon just thought it was general swelling. I can tell you I feel tons better since it has gone down. I still haven't found the perfect sleeping set-up yet.  I spent 3 weeks in the recliner and now try the bed with a large mountain of pillows all over the place!
Posts.Title: May 2012 Mastectomies? Still_Snarky Fearlessfoot

Posts.Content: Aug 9, 2012 10:46AM steelersluver wrote: Karenr1028c, I still go to physical therapy for axillary webbing (cording) with swelling and loss of range-of-motion.  In my case, the "cords" can be seen very clearly starting under my arm, but in milder cases you may not see it. I had full node dissection as opposed to just SNB, but I would guess it could happen with a SNB as well.  My SNB side is just about normal. You should consider asking for a referral to a lymphadema physical therapy specialist if you have concerns to get it checked out.
Posts.Title: May 2012 Mastectomies? Still_Snarky Fearlessfoot

Posts.Content: May 31, 2012 07:29PM steelersluver wrote: I finally got my last two drains out after 3 weeks.  It is nice to be able to tuck my shirt in if I want!  I also got my first fill, and discovered I'm not the whole way numb by the port on one side...didn't expect that! My muscle is tight, so they only put 40cc in mine at a time, and I don't feel bad at all.  I won't see the MO until the 12th, but they have told me to expect chemo and a port due to the one node and lousey veins.  They also expect the MO to request a PET scan, so it is nice to hear Digital Cowgirl got through it well.  How long did it take?  I also got a physical therapy referral to the lymphedema specialist to try to work on the stiffness and swelling on the left side.  Figures that I can't feel most of my arm on that side, but the port area is the one area that isn't numb!  I'm still happy to be moving along in the process now.
Posts.Title: May 2012 Mastectomies? Still_Snarky Fearlessfoot

Posts.Content: Jun 15, 2012 07:21AM steelersluver wrote: callindearg, I'm exactly 5 weeks out today with TE's, and like others have said, camping shouldn't be a problem, but sleeping on the ground in a sleeping bag may be an issue for you.  Getting comfortable is tough at times.  My drains were in for 3 weeks, but a lot of people get them out quicker.  Pain is very manageable with ocassional tylenol at this point.  Your bigger issue will involve conflicts with other tests, etc. you may need to have done.  For example, I needed a bone scan, ct scan, and MUGA test this week, and start chemo next week.  I also have cording from the lymph node removal, and have had difficulty getting PT scheduled between waiting for the drains and the other tests that needed to take priority.  In the end, it's one of those things that will vary by person.  I think you'll need to be flexible. Being a back sleeper will definitely help you.  I did wake up from surgery with a catheter.  They removed it very early the next morning.  I asked to have it out the first evening, but they suggested waiting because with all the IV's, needing to go to the rest room frequently could be an issue.  It's also difficult to go when you first get it out sometimes.
Posts.Title: May 2012 Mastectomies? Still_Snarky Fearlessfoot

Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2012 05:26PM steelersluver wrote: Diana NM - I was on Keflex for 3 weeks while waiting to get the drains out, but nothing since then. Still Snarky - I just got my physical therapy referral due to "cording" on the side they removed the lymph nodes.  I'm glad to see you feel it helps even if it is painful at the time.  I could not get fit in until next Thursday because I have so many other appointments scheduled for a second fill (more nervous than for the first since I now know I'm not completely numb), the MO, the RO, and whoever else I've forgotten about!
Posts.Title: May 2012 Mastectomies? Still_Snarky Fearlessfoot

Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2012 06:14AM steelersluver wrote: On the side my lymph nodes were removed, it does feel like a wire is attached from my upper side through my armpit, to my elbow.  I cannot lift my arm very far, but when i do, you can see what literally looks like several cords in my underarm that seem to be preventing me from lifting the arm.  This is definitely the worst part of the whole thing for me, even considering 3 weeks of drains.  I got the physical therapy referral from the breast surgeon, but I would think you could also get one from the plastic surgeon if you are having problems.
Posts.Title: May 2012 Mastectomies? Still_Snarky Fearlessfoot

Posts.Content: Jun 19, 2012 08:55AM steelersluver wrote: Marcia1111 - I have TE's and my plastic surgeon told me that after the initial post-op period, I do not need to wear anything for support.  I've been wearing tank tops mostly to mask the lumpiness.
Posts.Title: May 2012 Mastectomies? Still_Snarky Fearlessfoot

Posts.Content: May 16, 2012 12:52PM steelersluver wrote: Hi all, I'm done and resting at home from my May 11 BMX with TE.  I unexpectedly had to have 34 nodes removed after the sentinel biopsy was positive.  I'm still waiting for the pathology and some info how this will impact my reconstruction process and chemo was not weighed into anything previously.  I'm having a lot of difficulty with the arm that had the nodes removed (pain and movement issues both), but the rest of the recovery is not far off what I expected.  The stress of the days leading up to it are definitely the worst part as everyone else has mentioned. I'm still zapped from the anesthesia, but every day gets a bit better.  Good luck to all still waiting!

Posts.Content: Jun 9, 2012 02:49PM steelersluver wrote: dmarie71.  I have sjorgens also and my rheumatologist cleared me to have reconstruction with TE and implants.  I'd suggest you talk to your rheumatologist if you have one.  Get on it quick if you do not have one yet as there is often a wait list to be seen.
Posts.Title: Sjorgen's Syndrome and Implant Reconstruction dmarie71 steelersluver

Posts.Content: Apr 29, 2014 09:39AM steelersluver wrote: When I chose to have TE's placed at the time of my BMX, I was not expecting to need rads.  I ended up needing rads, but my PS did the exchange surgery right after chemo (before I started rads). She felt the failure rate was decreased this way. I got a minor incision infection because my counts were still down, but didn't have significant complications.  However, after rads, the scar tissue increased to the point of ultimately causing a frozen shoulder (the worst was the lymph node area, but around the implant too).  I've been working with my LE therapist for several months to try to break up the scar tissue, but have had only slight progress.  The scar tissue causes a good bit of pain, and the therapist thinks I may ultimately need to reduce the size of the implant and have some of the scar tissue removed.  The non-radiated side is great, but would also need reduced for symmetry.  I've had a lot of surgery in the past 2 years, so I'm riding out the therapy for a bit and consulting the PS this summer. I guess the radiation is just very hard on the healthy tissues. By having exchange before rads, the skin does seem to heal better after surgery, but the overall tissue damage is still an issue.
Posts.Title: Anyone with successful implant ...radiated breast? tcklme1 Moderators
